questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of fever, headache, earache, and sore throat that is worse when swallowing. He has not had a runny nose or cough. He had a similar problem 1 year ago for which he was prescribed amoxicillin, but after developing a skin rash, facial swelling, and dyspnea he was switched to a different medication. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 75th percentile for height and the 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 136/min, and respirations are 28/min. Examination of the oral cavity reveals a bright red tongue with prominent papillae, a red uvula, and an enlarged right tonsil covered by a whitish membrane. The deep cervical lymph nodes are enlarged and tender. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

S. pyogenes is the most common cause of bacterial tonsillitis and is uniformly sensitive to penicillin, making penicillin V the first-line treatment. However, given this patient's history of allergic reaction to amoxicillin (e.g., skin rash and facial swelling), penicillin antibiotics are contraindicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Total tonsillectomy poses a risk of postoperative bleeding. Indications for tonsillectomy include chronic tonsillitis, suspected tonsillar neoplasm, obstructive sleep apnea (due to extreme hypertrophy of the tonsils), and multiple recent recurrences of acute tonsillitis. Total tonsillectomy is not a suitable initial treatment for a child with an uncomplicated disease course, no signs of peritonsillar abscess, and only two episodes of acute tonsillitis within a year.

C) INCORRECT:

Subtotal tonsillectomy poses a risk of postoperative bleeding. Indications for tonsillectomy include chronic tonsillitis, suspected tonsillar neoplasm, obstructive sleep apnea (due to extreme hypertrophy of the tonsils), and multiple recent recurrences of acute tonsillitis. Subtotal tonsillectomy is not a suitable initial treatment for a child with an uncomplicated disease course, no signs of peritonsillar abscess, and only two episodes of acute tonsillitis within a year.

D) INCORRECT:

The whitish membrane seen covering this patient's tonsil could be a finding of oral Candida infection (i.e., thrush), which is typically treated with fluconazole. However, in a healthy child with a fever and acute tonsillitis, this whitish membrane is more likely due to tonsillar exudates. Fungal infections are more common in immunosuppressed or systemically ill individuals.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with tonsillitis that is likely due to a bacterial infection, which is normally treated with penicillin V. However, penicillins are contraindicated in this patient because of his past severe IgE-mediated allergic reaction to another penicillin antibiotic. Macrolides, such as clarithromycin or azithromycin, are the antibiotic of choice to treat acute bacterial tonsillitis in patients with a history of a severe penicillin allergy. If local macrolide resistance rates are high, clindamycin should be considered. Before initiating antibiotic therapy for suspected acute group A streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis, a rapid strep test should be obtained to confirm GAS infection.

See “Recommended antibiotic regimens for acute GAS pharyngitis” table.

F) INCORRECT:

Cefixime is a 3rd generation cephalosporin and up to 10% of patients with a penicillin allergy are also allergic to cephalosporins. Cephalosporins may be considered in patients with previous nonsevere reactions to penicillin (i.e., reactions without angioedema or anaphylaxis) but should not be used in patients who have had a previous severe reaction to penicillin. Moreover, when cephalosporins are used for the treatment of tonsillitis or pharyngitis, 1st generation cephalosporins (e.g., cephalexin, cefadroxil) are preferred; 3rd generation cephalosporins are least active among all cephalosporins against gram-positive bacteria such as S. pyogenes.
questions.hint: A modified Centor score of 5 (age 3–14 years, swollen tonsil with an exudate, tender anterior cervical lymph nodes, temperature > 100.4°F or > 38°C, and absence of cough) indicates a high likelihood of acute bacterial tonsillitis, which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. This patient also appears to have had a severe allergic reaction to amoxicillin in the past as suggested by the facial swelling (angioedema) and dyspnea.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician with a 2-day history of fever, chills, malaise, and a sore throat. He has been otherwise healthy and receives no medications. Growth and development are appropriate for age. Immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.4°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 121/71 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 100% on room air. Examination shows discrete 1–2-mm papulovesicular lesions on the posterior oropharynx and general erythema of the tonsils bilaterally. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with the cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rheumatic fever is associated with group A Streptococcus (GAS) infection, which also causes acute tonsillopharyngitis (strep throat). GAS tonsillitis is a common cause of acute tonsillopharyngitis in children between the ages of 5–15 years. As in this case, the first manifestations of GAS tonsillitis are fever, sore throat, and pharyngeal redness. However, papulovesicular lesions in the posterior pharynx are not consistent with this diagnosis. Tonsillar exudate and swollen, tender cervical lymph nodes would be expected instead.
Image Description:

Oropharynx of a child presenting with fever and sore throat

The tonsils are bilaterally enlarged and yellow-white exudates are visible at the openings of the tonsillar crypts. The soft palate, anterior tonsillar pillars, and the uvula are erythematous and edematous.

Tonsillar inflammation and exudates are characteristic features of acute bacterial tonsillitis, which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (group A Beta-hemolytic streptococcus).

B) INCORRECT:

Condylomata lata is a typical manifestation of secondary syphilis (i.e., infection with Treponema pallidum). The primary lesions of syphilis (chancres) are usually found in the anogenital area but may also appear in the posterior pharynx. Pharyngeal syphilis usually manifests with papules in the oral cavity that develop into painless ulcers. While early stages are often asymptomatic, some patients may complain of a sore throat. However, infection with T. pallidum in children most commonly occurs via sexual contact or vertical transmission from mother to child (i.e., during pregnancy or at birth) and is therefore unlikely in this 7-year-old boy.

C) INCORRECT:

Burkitt lymphoma is associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, which also causes infectious mononucleosis (IM). IM may manifest with acute fever, malaise, and tonsillopharyngitis. However, patients would usually have reddened, enlarged tonsils with white and grey deposits rather than papulovesicular lesions. Additionally, generalized lymphadenopathy and/or hepatosplenomegaly can occur and last up to a month. While IM is most commonly seen in individuals 15–24 years of age, EBV infection is often asymptomatic in younger children.
Image Description:

Enlarged, inflamed tonsil (green overlay) with gray-white deposits (white outline) in a patient with infectious mononucleosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Infective endocarditis may be caused by Viridans streptococci, which, together with anaerobes, is responsible for Ludwig's angina (LA). Although LA may occur in children, it is more common in young adults following odontogenic infections. It is characterized by rapidly progressing bilateral cellulitis of the neck and submandibular space. While fever and oropharyngeal erythema support the diagnosis, additional complaints (e.g., mouth pain, stiff neck, difficulty swallowing), as well as an elevated/protruding tongue, and submandibular swelling, would be expected in LA. This child's oropharyngeal lesions cannot be explained by this diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Herpetic whitlow is a common complication of herpetic gingivostomatitis, especially in young children (due to thumb sucking) and healthcare workers exposed to oral secretions (e.g., dentists). Both conditions are usually caused by herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1). Although herpetic gingivostomatitis also presents with fever, sore throat, pharyngeal redness, and multiple small vesicles, the oral lesions are typically located in the anterior pharynx and the lips, not the posterior pharynx. Moreover, it most commonly affects children 1–5 years of age.
Image Description:

Multiple red erosions can be seen on the lips. Intact vesicles with surrounding erythema are visible on the tongue.

This is the characteristic appearance of herpetic gingivostomatitis.

F) CORRECT:

Herpangina is most common in children between the ages of 3–10 years and infections occur most frequently in summer and fall. As in this case, the first manifestations of the disease are usually oropharyngeal lesions and a sore throat. Coxsackie A virus is the most common underlying pathogen, which also causes hand, foot, and mouth disease. The two conditions often occur concomitantly.
Image Description:

Several small vesicles and partially confluent yellow-white ulcers with an erythematous rim are visible on the inflamed soft palate.

This is the typical appearance of herpangina, an infection caused by the coxsackie A virus. The enanthem typically starts as painful, herpes-like vesicles on the oropharynx that then break down to form shallow, painful ulcers.
questions.hint: Abrupt-onset fever, sore throat, and multiple 1-mm papules and vesicles on the posterior oropharynx and tonsils are consistent with herpangina.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of sore throat for the past 2 days. During this period, he has had intermittent nausea and has vomited once. The patient has no cough, hoarseness, or rhinorrhea. He had similar symptoms at the age of 5 years that resolved spontaneously. He is otherwise healthy. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 108/70 mm Hg. Head and neck examination shows an erythematous pharynx with grayish exudates overlying the palatine tonsils. There is no lymphadenopathy. A rapid antigen detection test for group A streptococcus is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of antiviral capsid antigen IgM antibody

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antistreptolysin O (ASO) titer measurement is part of the workup for sequelae of streptococcal infection (e.g., rheumatic fever). ASO titer is not useful in diagnosing acute streptococcal infection because antibody levels take about 2 weeks to rise, and do not peak until 3–5 weeks after infection; antibody levels reflect past, rather than current infections. This patient has only been symptomatic for 2 days, therefore an ASO titer would likely be negative, even if his symptoms were due to streptococcal infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up are indicated for patients with typical symptoms of viral tonsillitis (e.g., rhinorrhea, oral ulcers, hoarse voice, and/or cough). This patient has a nonspecific presentation that requires further testing to rule out bacterial tonsillitis. If left untreated, bacterial tonsillitis increases the risk of rheumatic fever, poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis, and the spread of infection (e.g., peritonsillar abscess).

C) INCORRECT:

Measurement of antiviral capsid antigen IgM antibodies is used as a confirmatory test in patients with clinical suspicion of infectious mononucleosis. While patients with IM often have tonsillitis/pharyngitis, this patient lacks further symptoms such as cervical lymphadenopathy, fever, and hepatosplenomegaly. Moreover, symptoms typically occur in adolescents and young adults.

D) INCORRECT:

Penicillin V is the treatment of choice for patients with acute group A streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis and no penicillin allergy. However, this patient requires further testing before antibiotic treatment is indicated. The American College of Physicians recommends empiric antibiotics in patients with a modified Centor score of ≥ 4. This patient's score is 3 (< 15 years of age, tonsillar exudates and swelling, no cough). The Infectious Diseases Society of America and The American Academy of Pediatrics recommend treatment only in patients with confirmed group A streptococcal pharyngitis. In patients with penicillin allergy, macrolides like clarithromycin or azithromycin are first-line options.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has acute tonsillitis with no specific signs of viral illness (e.g., conjunctivitis, hoarseness, cough, stomatitis). The gold standard for diagnosing bacterial tonsillitis is a throat culture, which can identify the underlying pathogen and determine its antibiotic sensitivity. The rapid strep antigen test has poor sensitivity but high specificity. Children and adolescents with a negative rapid strep test should have a throat culture to rule out bacterial infection; up to 30% of infections are missed with rapid antigen detection testing. If the rapid strep antigen test is positive, antibiotic therapy can be started without confirmatory throat culture. If bacterial infection is ruled out (i.e., both antigen testing and culture are negative), observation and symptomatic management (e.g., acetaminophen, NSAIDs) are indicated.
questions.hint: This child presents with a sore throat and grayish exudates overlying the palatine tonsils, which is suggestive of acute tonsillitis.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 1-week history of fever, fatigue, and throat pain. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Physical examination shows bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. Oral examination shows the findings in the photograph. A peripheral blood smear shows lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. A heterophile antibody test is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation by the physician?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin therapy is indicated for tonsillopharyngitis caused by Group A Streptococcus (GAS). GAS tonsillopharyngitis typically manifests with fever, throat pain, and cervical lymphadenopathy. However, it does not cause lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes or a positive heterophile antibody test. Oral amoxicillin therapy is not used to treat Epstein-Barr virus infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Antiretroviral therapy is primarily used to treat human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. Acute HIV infection can manifest with fever, fatigue, throat pain, and lymphadenopathy and can rarely cause a positive heterophile antibody test. However, it does not cause lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. In addition, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of acute HIV infection, such as headache, weight loss, myalgias, arthralgias, an exanthematous rash, nausea, diarrhea, and lymphocytopenia. Antiretroviral therapy is not used to treat Epstein-Barr virus infections.

C) INCORRECT:

Bone marrow biopsy is used to evaluate various hematologic conditions, including acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), which typically manifests with fever, fatigue, and lymphadenopathy and can rarely cause a positive heterophile antibody test. However, it does not cause throat pain, the exudates seen in the photograph, or lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. In addition, this patient lacks other typical findings of ALL, such as weight loss, bone pain, thrombocytopenia, and lymphoblasts on a peripheral blood smear. Bone marrow biopsy does not have a role in the evaluation or management of Epstein-Barr virus infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Diphtheria antitoxin and antibiotics (e.g., penicillin G) are used to treat diphtheria, an infectious disease caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Respiratory diphtheria typically involves the tonsillopharyngeal area and manifests with fever, fatigue, throat pain, cervical lymphadenopathy, and white-gray pseudomembranes on the tonsils (caused by bacteria, epithelial cells, and inflammatory cells). However, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of respiratory diphtheria, including swelling of the anterior neck and difficulty breathing. Moreover, this condition is very rare due to widespread immunization (e.g., with DTaP).

E) CORRECT:

This patient has infectious mononucleosis (IM), a condition caused by Epstein-Barr virus. IM is most common among adolescents and typically manifests with fever, fatigue, throat pain, tonsillopharyngitis, bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, and lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. Although nonspecific, a positive heterophile antibody test supports the diagnosis. Treatment for IM is mainly supportive (e.g., fluids, antipyretics, analgesics). Approximately 50% of patients with IM develop splenomegaly, which increases the risk of splenic rupture, a rare but life-threatening complication. Though more than half of cases of splenic rupture occur spontaneously, patients with IM should avoid strenuous physical activity that may precipitate this complication (e.g., contact sports) for at least 4 weeks after the initial onset of symptoms.

Administering amoxicillin or ampicillin to patients with infectious mononucleosis (e.g., if they were thought to have streptococcal pharyngitis) can precipitate a maculopapular rash.

F) INCORRECT:

This patient has infectious mononucleosis, a condition caused by Epstein-Barr virus. Infectious mononucleosis spreads primarily through salivary secretions (e.g., via kissing or contamination of objects with saliva); patients with this condition do not need to avoid crowded places.
questions.hint: The photograph shows massively enlarged, erythematous tonsils that are covered with purulent, white-gray exudates. This form of tonsillopharyngitis is caused by Epstein-Barr virus.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to the physician because of a sore throat, dry cough, headache, and runny nose for the past 3 days. During this period, he has had no fever or difficulty breathing. He has psoriasis and erectile dysfunction. He lives with his wife and their two children. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 21 years. He rarely drinks alcohol and does not use drugs recreationally. Current medications include topical triamcinolone acetonide and sildenafil as needed. He appears fatigued. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Examination of the throat shows erythema of the tonsils and pharynx without exudates. There are erythematous plaques with silver-white scales on the patient's elbows and knees. The remainder of the examination shows no further abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain rapid test for group A Streptococcus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin is a beta-lactam antibiotic that can be used to treat bacterial pharyngitis caused by group A Streptococcus, which can manifest with sore throat and erythema of the tonsils and pharynx. However, it does not usually cause a cough. In addition, streptococcal pharyngitis more commonly develops in young adults and typically causes fevers, tonsillar exudates, and cervical lymphadenopathy. This patient's clinical presentation is more consistent with viral pharyngitis, which should not be treated with antibiotics.

B) INCORRECT:

Chest x-rays are often obtained during the evaluation of patients who have a cough to evaluate for evidence of pneumonia, a lower respiratory tract infection. However, this patient's symptoms (sore throat, rhinorrhea, erythema of the tonsils and pharynx) are more consistent with pharyngitis, an upper respiratory tract infection that does not require a chest x-ray for evaluation. In addition, he does not have typical features of a lower respiratory tract infection (e.g., fever, shortness of breath).

C) INCORRECT:

A throat swab culture can be used to confirm a diagnosis of bacterial pharyngitis (e.g., caused by group A Streptococcus), which can manifest with sore throat and erythema of the tonsils and pharynx. However, bacterial pharyngitis does not usually cause a cough. In addition, it most commonly develops in young adults and typically causes fevers, tonsillar exudates, and cervical lymphadenopathy.

D) INCORRECT:

The rapid test for group A Streptococcus has 70–90% sensitivity for detecting streptococcal pharyngitis, which can manifest with sore throat and erythema of the tonsils and pharynx. However, streptococcal pharyngitis does not usually cause a cough. In addition, it most commonly develops in young adults and typically causes fevers, tonsillar exudates, and cervical lymphadenopathy.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation is most consistent with acute viral pharyngitis, a self-limited disease with symptoms that typically resolve without treatment 3–4 days after onset. Symptomatic treatment with rest, analgesics, and saltwater gargles can help alleviate discomfort.

F) INCORRECT:

Oseltamivir is a neuraminidase inhibitor used to treat influenza infection, which can manifest with sore throat, dry cough, headache, rhinorrhea, and erythema of the tonsils and pharynx without exudates. However, influenza infection also typically causes fevers, chills, arthralgia, and myalgias. In addition, oseltamivir therapy is most effective if initiated within 1–2 days of symptom onset; this patient has been symptomatic for 3 days.
questions.hint: This patient's acute-onset sore throat, dry cough, headache, and rhinorrhea, in combination with erythema of the tonsils and pharynx (without tonsilar exudates), are suggestive of uncomplicated viral pharyngitis.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old male college student presents with a 3-day history of rhinorrhea, sore throat, cough, fatigue, and malaise. He states that he has no fevers or chills. His medical history is unremarkable, and he has no allergies. He volunteers in an elementary after-school program, and several students have had a runny nose and cough recently. He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
On physical examination, his temperature is 37.6°C. The posterior oropharynx is erythematous; there is no tonsillar exudate, but tonsil enlargement is noted. The patient has mild tenderness to palpation of the anterior cervical nodes but no cervical lymphadenopathy.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: Measurement of antistreptococcal antibodies (streptolysin O and DNase B); prescribe penicillin if positive
A rapid antigen-detection test and throat culture to assess for group A streptococcal infection; prescribe penicillin if either test is positive
No additional testing; recommend symptomatic treatment with analgesics only

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sinus radiographs are rarely indicated for throat pain, unless the patient has associated facial pain, facial pressure, periorbital discomfort, swelling, or positional facial pain (maxillary or frontal) to indicate acute sinusitis in the setting of a viral process.

B) INCORRECT:

Antistreptococcal antibodies help support a diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever or poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis by confirming recent group A streptococcal infection, but these tests are not useful in establishing acute infection.

C) INCORRECT:

For patients who have a Centor score >2, testing for group A streptococcal infection with a rapid antigen-detection test and throat culture is recommended, with treatment if positive; guidelines regarding empiric treatment in this group vary. However, for a score of 0, no testing or antibiotic treatment is recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

Neck ultrasound could be considered in the setting of throat pain associated with a unilateral neck mass, especially if it is cystic in nature (pointing toward an inflamed second branchial cleft cyst during an episode of acute pharyngitis).

E) CORRECT:

In adult-aged patients with pharyngitis, the 4-point Centor criteria are used to estimate the risk for group A streptococcal infection and to determine whether additional testing or treatment is indicated. One point is given for each of the following criteria:

• Fever
• Absence of cough
• Tender cervical lymphadenopathy
• Tonsillar exudate

A score of 0 is associated with a risk for streptococcal infection that is < 2.5%; a score of 3 or 4 is associated with a risk of infection between 28% and 53%. For patients with a score of 0 (as in this scenario), no testing or antibiotic treatment is recommended. For patients who have a score > 2, testing for group A streptococcal infection with a rapid antigen-detection test and throat culture is recommended, with treatment if positive; guidelines regarding empiric treatment in this group vary.

For diagnosed group A streptococcal pharyngitis, penicillin is the treatment of choice. Azithromycin is an alternative for penicillin-allergic patients.

Key learning point: No diagnostic testing or empiric antibiotic treatment is needed for patients with pharyngitis who have a Centor score of 0

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man presents with a 24-hour history of subjective fever, shaking chills, generalized malaise, cough, and shortness of breath. Ten days ago, he experienced severe odynophagia, fever, and tender cervical lymphadenopathy that resolved after 3 days of ibuprofen.
On physical examination, his temperature is 39.5°C, his heart rate is 120 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, and his respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute. He looks acutely ill. His tonsils are erythematous. On the right side of his neck, there is tenderness to palpation anterior to his sternocleidomastoid muscle and mild erythema of the overlying skin. On lung examination, he has decreased breath sounds over both bases.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A chest radiograph reveals bilateral pulmonary infiltrates.
Which one of the following tests, if any, is preferred to confirm the suspected diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: CT of the neck without intravenous contrast
CT of the neck with intravenous contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT of the neck without contrast is not appropriate for diagnosing jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis because it cannot adequately visualize the vasculature.

B) CORRECT:

Jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis (also known as Lemierre syndrome) consists of anaerobic tonsillitis that causes septic thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein or one of its tributaries. Patients often present with fever, neck or throat pain, cough, chest pain, or shortness of breath following an episode of pharyngitis; metastatic complications, such as septic pulmonary emboli, are common. Jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis usually affects previously healthy adolescents and young adults. The most common causative organism is an anaerobe, Fusobacterium necrophorum, which is often part of the normal oropharyngeal flora.

CT of the neck with intravenous contrast is the best way to diagnose jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis because it completely visualizes the intracranial parts of the vasculature. It can also detect other complications, such as abscess formation and osteomyelitis. Classic findings of jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis on contrast-enhanced CT include enhancement or distention of the internal jugular vein with a filling defect within the lumen of the vessel.

Key learning point: The preferred diagnostic test for jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis (Lemierre syndrome) is CT of the neck with intravenous contrast.

C) INCORRECT:

Imaging is indicated in a patient with suspected jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis to establish the diagnosis and prevent further complications of this severe, potentially fatal condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Plain-film radiography is not appropriate for diagnosing jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis because it cannot adequately visualize the vasculature.

E) INCORRECT:

Doppler ultrasound can also be used to diagnose jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis, but it is not the preferred imaging modality given its inability to visualize structures underneath the mandible and clavicle and its lower sensitivity for detecting newly formed clots.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl presents with a sore throat and a fever. Two weeks ago, she was prescribed a 10-day course of amoxicillin after a rapid streptococcal-antigen test confirmed a diagnosis of streptococcal pharyngitis. Her symptoms improved within 3 days, and she refused to take further doses after day 4. A week after stopping the medication, she again started to have fevers (exceeding 38.5°C) and began to complain of a sore throat.
Her current heart rate is 120 beats per minute, her blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg, and her temperature is 38.7°C. Her oropharynx examination is notable for 2+ symmetric tonsils with white patches of exudate bilaterally. She has a tender 1-cm left-anterior cervical lymph node.
Another rapid streptococcal test is positive.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Administer a single dose of intramuscular benzathine penicillin G

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If the patient had completed the full course of initial therapy successfully and there were no concerns about adherence to oral therapy, acceptable treatment regimens would include repeating the same antibiotic (amoxicillin).

B) INCORRECT:

If the patient had completed the full course of initial therapy successfully and there were no concerns about adherence to oral therapy, acceptable treatment regimens would include either repeating the same antibiotic (amoxicillin) or using an alternative regimen, such as clindamycin.

C) INCORRECT:

If the patient had completed the full course of initial therapy successfully and there were no concerns about adherence to oral therapy, acceptable treatment regimens would include either repeating the same antibiotic (amoxicillin) or using an alternative regimen, such as a narrow-spectrum cephalosporin (e.g., cephalexin).

D) CORRECT:

A repeat positive result on streptococcal diagnostic testing can represent a variety of clinical scenarios. In an asymptomatic patient, such a positive test is likely to reflect chronic streptococcal carrier status. If the patient is symptomatic for pharyngitis and recently received antibiotic treatment for it, the possibilities include poor adherence to the initial treatment regimen, recurrent infection from a close contact with streptococcal infection or carriage, or (in rare cases) failure to eradicate the original infection.

Retreatment is recommended in patients who have symptomatic pharyngitis and positive streptococcal test results. Although multiple oral treatment regimens are acceptable, this patient has shown an unwillingness to take oral medication after symptoms resolve. Therefore, the most appropriate option for her is a single dose of intramuscular benzathine penicillin G to assure adherence.

Key learning point: When initial oral treatment for streptococcal pharyngitis fails because of poor adherence, the most appropriate next choice for treatment is intramuscular benzathine penicillin G.

E) INCORRECT:

Mere observation is not recommended, as the patient is symptomatic for pharyngitis and has a current, positive streptococcal test result. Although a viral pharyngitis should be considered in a patient who is a chronic streptococcal carrier, repeat treatment with antibiotic therapy is recommended in patients (such as this one) who have a positive test and recurrent symptoms consistent with streptococcal pharyngitis.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents with a 24-hour history of subjective fever, shaking chills, generalized malaise, cough, and shortness of breath. Ten days ago, he experienced severe odynophagia, fever, and tender cervical lymphadenopathy that resolved after 3 days of ibuprofen.
On physical examination, his temperature is 39.5°C, his heart rate is 120 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, and his respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute. He looks acutely ill. His tonsils are erythematous. On the right side of his neck, there is tenderness to palpation anterior to his sternocleidomastoid muscle and mild erythema of the overlying skin. On lung examination, he has decreased breath sounds over both bases.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A chest radiograph reveals bilateral pulmonary infiltrates.
Which one of the following tests, if any, is preferred to confirm the suspected diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: CT of the neck without intravenous contrast
CT of the neck with intravenous contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A specific imaging study is required to confirm the diagnosis of jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis.

B) INCORRECT:

CT of the neck without contrast is not appropriate for diagnosing jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis because it cannot adequately visualize the vasculature.

C) INCORRECT:

Plain-film radiography is not appropriate for diagnosing jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis because it cannot adequately visualize the vasculature.

D) INCORRECT:

Doppler ultrasound can also be used to diagnose jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis, but it is not the preferred imaging modality given its inability to visualize structures underneath the mandible and clavicle and its lower sensitivity for detecting newly formed clots.

E) CORRECT:

Jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis (Lemierre syndrome) consists of anaerobic tonsillitis that causes septic thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein or one of its tributaries. Patients often present with fever, neck or throat pain, cough, chest pain, or shortness of breath following an episode of pharyngitis; metastatic complications, such as septic pulmonary emboli, are common. Jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis usually affects previously healthy adolescents and young adults. The most common causative organism is an anaerobe, Fusobacterium necrophorum, which is often part of the normal oropharyngeal flora.

CT of the neck with intravenous contrast is the best way to diagnose jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis because it completely visualizes the intracranial parts of the vasculature. It can also detect other complications, such as abscess formation and osteomyelitis. Classic findings of jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis on contrast-enhanced CT include enhancement or distention of the internal jugular vein with a filling defect within the lumen of the vessel.

Key learning point: The preferred diagnostic test for jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis (Lemierre syndrome) is CT of the neck with intravenous contrast.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to the office because of a sore throat, dry cough, headache, and runny nose for the past 3 days. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Examination of the throat shows erythema of the tonsils and pharynx without exudates. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics, such as amoxicillin, can be used to treat bacterial pharyngitis caused by group A Streptococcus, which can manifest with sore throat and erythema of the tonsils and pharynx. However, it does not usually cause a cough. In addition, streptococcal pharyngitis more commonly develops in young adults and typically causes fevers, tonsillar exudates, and cervical lymphadenopathy. This patient's clinical presentation is more consistent with viral pharyngitis, which should not be treated with antibiotics.

B) INCORRECT:

Chest x-rays are often obtained during the evaluation of patients who have a cough to evaluate for evidence of pneumonia, a lower respiratory tract infection. However, this patient's symptoms (sore throat, rhinorrhea, erythema of the tonsils and pharynx) are more consistent with pharyngitis, an upper respiratory tract infection that does not require a chest x-ray for evaluation. In addition, he does not have typical features of a lower respiratory tract infection (e.g., fever, shortness of breath).

C) INCORRECT:

A throat swab culture can be used to confirm a diagnosis of bacterial pharyngitis (e.g., caused by group A Streptococcus), which can manifest with sore throat and erythema of the tonsils and pharynx. However, bacterial pharyngitis does not usually cause a cough. In addition, it most commonly develops in young adults and typically causes fevers, tonsillar exudates, and cervical lymphadenopathy.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation is most consistent with acute viral pharyngitis, a self-limited disease with symptoms that typically resolve without treatment 3–4 days after onset. Symptomatic treatment with rest, analgesics, and saltwater gargles can help alleviate discomfort.

Key learning point: Acute viral pharyngitis is self-limited and should be managed with symptomatic treatment rather than antibiotics or antivirals.

E) INCORRECT:

Antivirals, such as oseltamivir, are used to treat influenza infection, which can manifest with sore throat, dry cough, headache, rhinorrhea, and erythema of the tonsils and pharynx without exudates. However, influenza infection also typically causes fevers, chills, arthralgia, and myalgias. In addition, oseltamivir therapy is most effective if initiated within 1–2 days of symptom onset; this patient has been symptomatic for 3 days.
questions.hint: This patient's acute-onset sore throat, dry cough, headache, and rhinorrhea, in combination with erythema of the tonsils and pharynx (without tonsilar exudates), are suggestive of uncomplicated viral pharyngitis.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of a 1-week history of fever, fatigue, and throat pain. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Physical examination shows bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. Oral examination shows the findings in the photograph. A peripheral blood smear shows lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. A heterophile antibody test is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin therapy is indicated for tonsillopharyngitis caused by Group A Streptococcus (GAS). GAS tonsillopharyngitis typically manifests with fever, throat pain, and cervical lymphadenopathy. However, it does not cause lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes or a positive heterophile antibody test. Oral amoxicillin therapy is not used to treat Epstein-Barr virus infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Antiretroviral therapy is primarily used to treat human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. Acute HIV infection can manifest with fever, fatigue, throat pain, and lymphadenopathy and can rarely cause a positive heterophile antibody test. However, it does not cause lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. In addition, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of acute HIV infection, such as headache, weight loss, myalgias, arthralgias, an exanthematous rash, nausea, diarrhea, and lymphocytopenia. Antiretroviral therapy is not used to treat Epstein-Barr virus infections.

C) INCORRECT:

Bone marrow biopsy is used to evaluate various hematologic conditions, including acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), which typically manifests with fever, fatigue, and lymphadenopathy and can rarely cause a positive heterophile antibody test. However, it does not cause throat pain, the exudates seen in the photograph, or lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. In addition, this patient lacks other typical findings of ALL, such as weight loss, bone pain, thrombocytopenia, and lymphoblasts on a peripheral blood smear. Bone marrow biopsy does not have a role in the evaluation or management of Epstein-Barr virus infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Diphtheria antitoxin and antibiotics (e.g., penicillin G) are used to treat diphtheria, an infectious disease caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Respiratory diphtheria typically involves the tonsillopharyngeal area and manifests with fever, fatigue, throat pain, cervical lymphadenopathy, and white-gray pseudomembranes on the tonsils (caused by bacteria, epithelial cells, and inflammatory cells). However, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of respiratory diphtheria, including swelling of the anterior neck and difficulty breathing. Moreover, this condition is very rare due to widespread immunization (e.g., with DTaP).

E) CORRECT:

This patient has infectious mononucleosis (IM), a condition caused by Epstein-Barr virus. IM is most common among adolescents and typically manifests with fever, fatigue, throat pain, tonsillopharyngitis, bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. Although nonspecific, a positive heterophile antibody test supports the diagnosis. Treatment for IM is mainly supportive (e.g., fluids, antipyretics, analgesics). Approximately 50% of patients with IM develop splenomegaly, which increases the risk of splenic rupture, a rare but life-threatening complication. Though more than half of cases of splenic rupture occur spontaneously, patients with IM should avoid strenuous physical activity that may precipitate this complication (e.g., contact sports) for at least 4 weeks after the initial onset of symptoms.

Administering amoxicillin or ampicillin to patients with infectious mononucleosis (e.g., if they were thought to have streptococcal pharyngitis) can precipitate a maculopapular rash.

Key learning point: Infectious mononucleosis increases the risk of splenic rupture, so patients should avoid contact sports and strenuous activities for at least 4 weeks after symptom onset.
questions.hint: The photograph shows massively enlarged, erythematous tonsils that are covered with purulent, white-gray exudates. This form of tonsillopharyngitis is caused by Epstein-Barr virus.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the office with a 2-day history of fever, chills, malaise, and a sore throat. She has been otherwise healthy and receives no medications. Growth and development are appropriate for age. Immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101.4°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 121/71 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 100% on room air. Examination shows discrete 1–2-mm papulovesicular lesions on the posterior oropharynx and general erythema of the tonsils bilaterally (figure). Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with the cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rheumatic fever is associated with group A Streptococcus (GAS) infection, which also causes acute tonsillopharyngitis (strep throat). GAS tonsillitis is a common cause of acute tonsillopharyngitis in children between the ages of 5–15 years. As in this case, the first manifestations of GAS tonsillitis are fever, sore throat, and pharyngeal redness. However, papulovesicular lesions in the posterior pharynx are not consistent with this diagnosis. Tonsillar exudate and swollen, tender cervical lymph nodes would be expected instead.
Image Description:

Oropharynx of a child presenting with fever and sore throat

The tonsils are bilaterally enlarged and yellow-white exudates are visible at the openings of the tonsillar crypts. The soft palate, anterior tonsillar pillars, and the uvula are erythematous and edematous.

Tonsillar inflammation and exudates are characteristic features of acute bacterial tonsillitis, which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (group A Beta-hemolytic streptococcus).

B) INCORRECT:

Burkitt lymphoma is associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, which also causes infectious mononucleosis (IM). IM may manifest with acute fever, malaise, and tonsillopharyngitis. However, patients would usually have reddened, enlarged tonsils with white and grey deposits rather than papulovesicular lesions. Additionally, generalized lymphadenopathy and/or hepatosplenomegaly can occur and last up to a month. While IM is most commonly seen in individuals 15–24 years of age, EBV infection is often asymptomatic in younger children.
Image Description:

Enlarged, inflamed tonsil (green overlay) with gray-white deposits (white outline) in a patient with infectious mononucleosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Infective endocarditis may be caused by Viridans streptococci, which, together with anaerobes, is responsible for Ludwig's angina (LA). Although LA may occur in children, it is more common in young adults following odontogenic infections. It is characterized by rapidly progressing bilateral cellulitis of the neck and submandibular space. While fever and oropharyngeal erythema support the diagnosis, additional complaints (e.g., mouth pain, stiff neck, difficulty swallowing), as well as an elevated/protruding tongue, and submandibular swelling, would be expected in LA. This child's oropharyngeal lesions cannot be explained by this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Herpetic whitlow is a common complication of herpetic gingivostomatitis, especially in young children (due to thumb sucking) and healthcare workers exposed to oral secretions (e.g., dentists). Both conditions are usually caused by herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1). Although herpetic gingivostomatitis also presents with fever, sore throat, pharyngeal redness, and multiple small vesicles, the oral lesions are typically located in the anterior pharynx and the lips, not the posterior pharynx. Moreover, it most commonly affects children 1–5 years of age.
Image Description:

Multiple red erosions can be seen on the lips. Intact vesicles with surrounding erythema are visible on the tongue.

This is the characteristic appearance of herpetic gingivostomatitis.

E) CORRECT:

Herpangina is most common in children between the ages of 3–10 years and infections occur most frequently in summer and fall. As in this case, the first manifestations of the disease are usually oropharyngeal lesions and a sore throat. Coxsackie A virus is the most common underlying pathogen, which also causes hand, foot, and mouth disease. The two conditions often occur concomitantly.
Image Description:

Several small vesicles and partially confluent yellow-white ulcers with an erythematous rim are visible on the inflamed soft palate.

This is the typical appearance of herpangina, an infection caused by the coxsackie A virus. The enanthem typically starts as painful, herpes-like vesicles on the oropharynx that then break down to form shallow, painful ulcers.
questions.hint: Abrupt-onset fever, sore throat, and multiple 1-mm papules and vesicles on the posterior oropharynx and tonsils are consistent with herpangina.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man presents with a 3-day history of rhinorrhea, sore throat, cough, fatigue, and malaise. He volunteers in an elementary after-school program, and several students have had a runny nose and cough recently. On physical examination, his temperature is 37.6°C. The posterior oropharynx is erythematous; there is no tonsillar exudate, but the tonsils are enlarged. There is mild tenderness to palpation of the anterior cervical nodes but no cervical lymphadenopathy. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Measurement of antistreptococcal antibodies (streptolysin O and DNase B); prescribe penicillin if positive
A rapid antigen-detection test and throat culture to assess for group A streptococcal infection; prescribe penicillin if either test is positive
No additional testing; recommend symptomatic treatment with analgesics only

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sinus radiographs are rarely indicated for throat pain, unless the patient has associated facial pain, facial pressure, periorbital discomfort, swelling, or positional facial pain (maxillary or frontal) to indicate acute sinusitis in the setting of a viral process.

B) INCORRECT:

Antistreptococcal antibodies help support a diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever or poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis by confirming recent group A streptococcal infection, but these tests are not useful in establishing acute infection.

C) INCORRECT:

For patients who have a Centor score >2, testing for group A streptococcal infection with a rapid antigen-detection test and throat culture is recommended, with treatment if positive; guidelines regarding empiric treatment in this group vary. However, for a score of 0, no testing or antibiotic treatment is recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

Neck ultrasound could be considered in the setting of throat pain associated with a unilateral neck mass, especially if it is cystic in nature (pointing toward an inflamed second branchial cleft cyst during an episode of acute pharyngitis).

E) CORRECT:

In adult-aged patients with pharyngitis, the 4-point Centor criteria are used to estimate the risk for group A streptococcal infection and to determine whether additional testing or treatment is indicated. One point is given for each of the following criteria:

• Fever
• Absence of cough
• Tender cervical lymphadenopathy
• Tonsillar exudate

A score of 0 is associated with a risk for streptococcal infection that is < 2.5%; a score of 3 or 4 is associated with a risk of infection between 28% and 53%. For patients with a score of 0 (as in this scenario), no testing or antibiotic treatment is recommended. For patients who have a score > 2, testing for group A streptococcal infection with a rapid antigen-detection test and throat culture is recommended, with treatment if positive; guidelines regarding empiric treatment in this group vary.

For diagnosed group A streptococcal pharyngitis, penicillin is the treatment of choice. Azithromycin is an alternative for penicillin-allergic patients.

Key learning point: No diagnostic testing or empiric antibiotic treatment is needed for patients with pharyngitis who have a Centor score of 0

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the office because of a 3-day history of fever and sore throat that is worse when swallowing. He has not had a runny nose or cough. He had a similar problem 1 year ago for which he was prescribed amoxicillin, but after developing a severe allergic reaction was switched to a different medication. His immunizations are up-to-date. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 136/min, and respirations are 28/min. Examination of the oral cavity reveals a bright red tongue with prominent papillae, a red uvula, and an enlarged right tonsil covered by a whitish membrane. The deep cervical lymph nodes are enlarged and tender. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

S. pyogenes is the most common cause of bacterial tonsillitis and is uniformly sensitive to penicillin, making penicillin V the first-line treatment. However, given this patient's history of allergic reaction to amoxicillin, penicillin antibiotics are contraindicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Total tonsillectomy is associated with a high risk of postoperative bleeding and is not a suitable initial treatment for a child with an uncomplicated disease course and no signs of peritonsillar abscess. In addition, this child has had only two episodes of tonsillitis within the past year and does not meet the Paradise criteria for a tonsillectomy (recurrent tonsillitis consisting of ≥ 7 episodes in the past year, ≥ 5 episodes/year in the past 2 years, or ≥ 3 episodes/year in the past 3 years). Other indications for tonsillectomy include chronic tonsillitis, suspected tonsillar neoplasm, and obstructive sleep apnea (due to extreme hypertrophy of the tonsils).

C) INCORRECT:

Partial tonsillectomy carries the usual risks associated with surgery (e.g., postoperative bleeding, infection, etc.) and is therefore not suitable as the initial treatment in this patient, who has no signs of peritonsillar abscess and an uncomplicated course up to now.

D) INCORRECT:

The whitish membrane seen covering this patient's tonsil could be a finding of oral Candida infection (i.e., thrush), which is typically treated with fluconazole. However, in a healthy child with a fever and acute tonsillitis, this whitish membrane is more likely due to tonsillar exudates. Fungal infections are more common in immunosuppressed or systemically ill individuals.

E) CORRECT:

This patient is presenting with tonsillitis that is likely of bacterial etiology, which would normally be treated with penicillin V. However, penicillins are contraindicated in this patient because of his past severe IgE-mediated allergic reaction to another penicillin antibiotic. Macrolides, such as clarithromycin or azithromycin, are the antibiotic of choice to treat acute bacterial tonsillitis in patients with a history of severe penicillin allergy. If local macrolide resistance is a problem, clindamycin can also be considered.

See “Recommended antibiotic regimens for acute GAS pharyngitis” table.
questions.hint: A modified Centor score of 5 (age 3–14 years, swollen tonsil with an exudate, tender anterior cervical lymph nodes, temperature > 100.4°F or > 38°C, absent cough) indicates a high likelihood of acute bacterial tonsillitis, which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. This patient also had a severe allergic reaction to amoxicillin in the past.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old college student presents with a 2-day history of sore throat, mild fever, and fatigue, but no cough. Examination reveals mild tonsillar erythema and minimally enlarged anterior cervical lymph nodes. The throat is mildly tender, but there is no difficulty swallowing or respiratory distress. A rapid antigen detection test for group A Streptococcus is negative.

Temperature
37.8°C

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Viral pharyngitis is typically self-limiting, characterized by low-grade fever, mild sore throat, and fatigue. The negative rapid antigen detection test for group A Streptococcus supports a viral etiology, making antibiotics unnecessary. Symptomatic relief with analgesics, hydration, and rest is appropriate to manage symptoms and avoid unnecessary antibiotic use. This approach aligns with clinical guidelines for viral pharyngitis management.

Key learning point: In cases of sore throat with a negative rapid strep test, supportive treatment is appropriate as viral infections are common and self-limiting, and unnecessary antibiotic use should be avoided.

B) INCORRECT:

Throat culture is the gold standard for group A streptococcal infection but is mainly recommended for children. In adults, a negative rapid antigen detection test is reliable. The mild clinical presentation suggests a viral etiology, making further confirmation unnecessary.

C) INCORRECT:

Penicillin treats confirmed group A streptococcal pharyngitis. However, the negative rapid antigen detection test and mild clinical presentation suggest a viral cause. Initiating penicillin would be unnecessary and could lead to adverse effects and antimicrobial resistance.

D) INCORRECT:

Antiviral therapy is indicated for influenza if started within 48 hours of symptom onset. This patient lacks systemic symptoms typical of influenza, and the presentation aligns with benign viral pharyngitis, which is best managed with supportive care.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy presents with a 2-day history of fever, throat pain, and difficulty swallowing. His mother reports no cough or rhinorrhea. Examination shows swollen, erythematous tonsils with white patches and tender anterior cervical lymph nodes. He appears otherwise well, with no rash or abdominal pain.

Temperature
38.5°C

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluating his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Penicillin is the treatment for confirmed Group A Streptococcus pharyngitis. However, initiating antibiotics without diagnostic confirmation is premature, as viral causes of pharyngitis are common in children. Diagnostic testing, such as a rapid antigen detection test, should precede antibiotic therapy to avoid unnecessary treatment and resistance.

B) INCORRECT:

The Monospot test detects heterophile antibodies for Epstein-Barr virus, which causes infectious mononucleosis. This condition presents with fatigue, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly, which are absent in this patient. The boy's age and symptoms favor streptococcal pharyngitis over mononucleosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Anti-streptolysin O (ASO) titers indicate past streptococcal infection, peaking weeks after infection. They are useful for diagnosing complications like rheumatic fever but not for acute infection. In acute pharyngitis, direct detection methods like a rapid antigen detection test are more appropriate.

D) CORRECT:

The boy's symptoms, including fever, tonsillar exudates, and tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy without cough, suggest Group A Streptococcus pharyngitis. A rapid antigen detection test (RADT) is a quick and specific method to identify streptococcal antigens from a throat swab, making it an ideal initial diagnostic tool. In children, a negative RADT is often followed by a throat culture to confirm results, ensuring accurate diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic use.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected streptococcal pharyngitis, the Rapid Antigen Detection Test (RADT) is the best initial diagnostic step due to its quick turnaround time and ability to confirm the presence of Group A Streptococcus.
